review.title: For a Semantic Web based Peer-reviewing and Publication of Research Results
review.abstract: This article shows why the diffusion and peer-reviewing of research results would be more efficient, precise and relevant if all or at least some parts of the descriptions and peer-reviews of research results took the form of a fine-grained semantic network, within articles or knowledge bases, as part of the Semantic Web. This article also shows some ways this can be done and hence how research journal/proceeding publishers could allow this. So far, the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) has not proposed simple notations and cooperation protocols - similar to those illustrated or referred to in this article - but it now seems likely that Wikipedia/Wikidata, Google or the W3C will propose them sooner or later. Then, research journal/proceeding publishers and researchers may or may not quickly use this approach.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: The current use of research articles - and peer reviews of them - as a principal means of diffusion and validation of research results is known to have many problems. This article identifies the main cause of these problems as the use and verification of entire informal documents, but only variations of the "research results" seem to have been discussed or tried out, for example, "open access to articles" (after a certain time, or directly if the authors pay for them).
